thread.title: Former Cessna CEO part of Denver company crowdsourcing vertical takeoff business aircraft
thread.title_full: Former Cessna CEO part of Denver company crowdsourcing vertical takeoff business aircraft

author: Daniel McCoy
title: Former Cessna CEO part of Denver company crowdsourcing vertical takeoff business aircraft
text:
XTI Aircraft Company image XTI Aircraft Company is using crowdfunding in effort to build the TriFan 600. Officials at Denver-based XTI Aircraft Co. are using equity crowd funding to raise money to help build a business aircraft capable of vertical takeoffs and landings. XTI’s leadership includes a tie to Wichita. Board member Charles Johnson is a former CEO of Cessna Aircraft Co. , where he succeeded Russ Meyer in 2003. According to a report from the Denver Business Journal, the six-seat, fixed-wing aircraft — known as the TriFan 600 — will come with a price tag of $10 million to $12 million. The company has been developing the aircraft for over two years and its StartEngine page says that after raising sufficient funds it hopes to build and fly the first prototype of the TriFan 600 in another two-and-a-half years. It says it views equity crowdsourcing as a way of involving all those interested in the project as true stakeholders.
